results.title: Energy
results.brief_description: Shows the mining of coal, its conversion into electrical energy, and the problems enocuntered in this conversion such as the disposal of waste products. Also looks at atomic power stations and their inherent problems. The concept of tidal power as an alternative source is mentioned. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.
results.description: Shows the mining of coal, its conversion into electrical energy, and the problems enocuntered in this conversion such as the disposal of waste products. Also looks at atomic power stations and their inherent problems. The concept of tidal power as an alternative source is mentioned. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: A Lesson for teacher
results.creator_credit: John Mansfield and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
In 1976 Dr Neville Bennett of Lancaster University published his research report evaluating the success and failure of various systems used in British primary schools. This was the first major attempt to analyse scientifically just how much children learn in establishments ranging from the most progressive, open-plan schools, to the most traditional. The publication of the report was an important educational event, and it will give rise to much questioning about the direction of current trends in British education. The report revealed that in one year pupils taught by formal methods can be as much as five months in advance educationally of those taught by the free style.

results.title: Atmosphere in motion
results.creator_credit: William Kay and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Explores the causes and effects of atmospheric motion. Time-lapse photography makes the ordinarily slow movement of clouds readily observable and uses experiments to illustrate and explain other atmospheric phenomena.

results.title: News
results.creator_credit: Tim King, Mike Wooller and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: Shows how the news is gathered and presented on the 9 o’clock news on BBC1, including the build-up of tension among the team when making time and location checks. Great “bird’s-eye” view of the news team.

results.title: The River that came clean
results.creator_credit: Christopher Riley and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
An environmental success story that begins by emphasising the role of sewage as a major pollutant of the River Thames since the mid 19th century. Shows evidence of the great increase in fish and bird life after a cleaning process was instigated. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.
results.description:

results.title: Children of Peru
results.creator_credit: Michael Andrews and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Documents new agricultural methods and technological discoveries in Peru and the beneficial effects these might have on the health and nutrition of the children of Peru if implemented. Narrated by paul Vaughan. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.
results.description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Documents new agricultural methods and technological discoveries in Peru and the beneficial effects these might have on the health and nutrition of the children of Peru if implemented. Narrated by paul Vaughan. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.
description_for_label:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Documents new agricultural methods and technological discoveries in Peru and the beneficial effects these might have on the health and nutrition of the children of Peru if implemented. Narrated by paul Vaughan. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.

results.title: Ghana: ways forward
results.brief_description: Considers that progress in the form pf automation may have come too early for a country like Ghana. Now many of the population are idle. Looks at government instigated self-help programmes, which utilise the country’s biggest resource - people and aid in productivity.
results.description: Considers that progress in the form pf automation may have come too early for a country like Ghana. Now many of the population are idle. Looks at government instigated self-help programmes, which utilise the country’s biggest resource - people and aid in productivity.
description_for_label: Considers that progress in the form pf automation may have come too early for a country like Ghana. Now many of the population are idle. Looks at government instigated self-help programmes, which utilise the country’s biggest resource - people and aid in productivity.
